title-group.title: Monte Carlo single-cell dosimetry of Auger-electron emitting radionuclides
title-group.short-title: Monte Carlo single-cell dosimetry of Auger-electron emitting radionuclides
title-group.ej-title: Monte Carlo single-cell dosimetry of Auger-electron emitting radionuclides

address-group.address: Department of Medical Physics, University of Ioannina, Ioannina 451 10, Greece
Department of Computer Science, University of Ioannina, Ioannina 451 10, Greece
Radiation Biophysics Group, Department of Oncology-Pathology, Karolinska Institutet, Box 260, SE-171 76 Stockholm, Sweden
Author to whom any correspondence should be addressed

abstract.heading: Abstract
abstract.p: A hybrid Monte Carlo transport scheme combining event-by-event and condensed-history simulation with a full account of energy-loss straggling was used to study the dosimetric characteristics of the Auger-emitting radionuclides 67Ga, 99mTc, 111In, 123I, 125I and 201Tl at the single-cell level. The influence of the intracellular localization of the Auger radionuclide upon cellular S-values, radial dose rate profiles and dose-volume-histograms (DVHs) was investigated. For the case where the radiopharmaceutical was either internalized into the cytoplasm or remained bound onto the cell surface (non-internalized), the dose to the cell nucleus was found to differ significantly from the MIRD values and other published data. In this case, the assumption of a homogeneous distribution throughout the cell is shown to significantly overestimate the nuclear dose. A dosimetric case study relevant to the radioimmunotherapy of single lymphoma B-cells with 125I and 123I is presented.

sec-level1.heading: Introduction
sec-level1.p: Absorbed dose calculations in targeted radionuclide therapy are conventionally based on the medical internal radiation dose (MIRD) formalism under the assumption of a uniform activity distribution (Kassis 1992, Howell 1994, Sgouros 2005, Stabin 2006). In such cases, it is implicitly assumed that all irradiated tumor cells will receive the same average tumor dose. However, various experimental studies for several radiopharmaceuticals that were performed on cell cultures in vitro have revealed that the distribution of activity in tumors is highly non-uniform (Makrigiorgos et al 1990a, 1990b, Griffiths et al 1999, Kriehuber et al 2004, Neti and Howell 2006). The heterogeneous distribution of radioactivity has been one of the main reasons for the widespread usage of beta emitters which by virtue of their long irradiation range (spanning several cell diameters) are capable of cross-irradiating non-targeted tumor cells, thus, to some extent, counteracting the effects of heterogeneity (Kassis 2008). Although the importance of the crossfire effect in solid tumor-targeted radionuclide therapy is indisputable (Boswell and Brechbiel 2005), it comes with the price of increased normal tissue damage, especially in hematologic or disseminated disease which may exhibit single cells in the circulation. The therapeutic advantages of Auger emitters in such cases have been extensively discussed in the literature (Kassis 2004). Theoretically, Auger-emitting radionuclides provide two of the requirements for optimized targeted therapy, namely, high level of cytotoxicity and short range radiobiological effectiveness (Howell 2008).

From a dosimetric point of view most Auger electrons have sub-keV energies and a range in tissue up to a few hundred nanometers. Thus, the subcellular localization of Auger-emitting radionuclides becomes crucial since absorbed dose calculations in targeted radionuclide therapy would be most effective if performed on a spatial scale comparable to the penetration range of the emitted radiation (Roeske et al 2008). In fact, due to specific mechanisms that localize the drug in particular areas of tumor cells (Pauwels et al 1998), the intracellular distribution and absorbed dose profile of Auger emitters may also be nonuniform with a profound impact on the cellular biological response (Charlton 1986, Charlton et al 1994, Humm and Cobb 1990, Bardi√®s and Pihet 2000, Nikjoo et al 2008). A large and self-consistent body of radiobiological data has shown that the radiotoxicity and the therapeutic potential of Auger emitters varied with their subcellular distribution (Kassis 2004). For instance, Kassis and co-workers in a series of experimental studies (Kassis et al 1980, 1982, 1983, 1985, 1988) clearly indicated that nuclear rather than cytoplasmic or surface decay contributed primarily to the cytosidal effect for several Auger emitters. These considerations have motivated us to work on the development of effective carrier systems for their intranuclear delivery and localization in close proximity to nuclear DNA (Haefliger et al 2005, Buchegger et al 2006, Boswell and Brechbiel 2007, Pouget et al 2008, Costantini et al 2008).

Although the internal dosimetry performed in patients receiving targeted radionuclide therapy is nowhere near the sophistication of external beam dosimetry protocols, absorbed dose calculations still play an important role in assessing the efficacy of new radiopharmaceuticals (Stabin 2003). A variety of techniques have been employed for determining the absorbed dose at the subcellular level by Auger emitters, including both analytical and Monte Carlo (MC) methods. Early studies made extensive use of Berger's (1973) scaled dose point kernel data for monoenergetic electrons (Jungerman et al 1984, Faraggi et al 1994, 1998, Gardin et al 1995). A systematic dosimetry study for several Auger emitters distributed in different subcellular compartments (surface, cytoplasm, nucleus, whole cell) was carried out by Goddu et al (1997) using the analytic range-energy expression of Cole (1969), as improved by Howell et al (1989). This work constitutes the MIRD cellular S-values. More recent work along these lines includes the study of Yuan et al (2008) who used the MIRD analytic approach to illustrate the influence of heterogeneity upon the cellular S-values of several Auger emitters. An alternative approach is the use of MC codes to simulate stochastically the energy loss of electrons in matter during their slowing down process (Nikjoo et al 2006). Owing to their high degree of spatial resolution (i.e. down to the molecular level), MC track structure codes simulating all collisions in an event-by-event manner are most suitable for the dosimetry of Auger emitters. There are many reports on MC-based dosimetry at the cell level for low-energy Auger electrons using different track-structure codes (Charlton 1986, Booz et al 1987, Charlton et al 1989, Wright et al 1990, Pomplun 1991, √únak 1997, √únak et al 1997, Ft√°ƒçnikov√° and B√∂hm 2000, Li et al 2001, Nikjoo et al 1996, 2000, 2002, 2008, Hindorf et al 2005, 2007, Emfietzoglou et al 2007, 2008, Chen 2008, Liu et al 2009). However, differences in the cross-section models used for describing the interactions of sub-keV electrons with water (Uehara et al 1999, Emfietzoglou and Nikjoo 2005), which is the medium used to approximate the cellular milieu, can sometimes lead to sizeable differences in electron track structure parameters that influence the dosimetry at the subcellular level (Nikjoo et al 2008). It is therefore important that calculations are carried out with many different codes in order to assess the sensitivity of the results on the cross-section input or other transport approximations used in the codes.

In this work, we present MC calculated absorbed dose and dose rates as well as dose-volume-histograms (DVHs) at the level of an isolated single cell for six widely used Auger-emitting radionuclides (67Ga, 99mTc, 111In, 123I, 125I and 201Tl) using the MC4 track structure code (Emfietzoglou et al 2000a, 2000b, Bousis et al 2008a). The influence of the subcellular localization of the Auger radionuclide is investigated in some detail. In addition, dosimetric calculations are presented for the clinically relevant case of non-internalizing (surface-bound) and internalizing monoclonal antibody (MAb) labeled with either 125I or 123I that targets a typical lymphoma B-cell. The Auger emission spectra (including Coster‚ÄìKronig and IC electrons) used in the present work (see table 1) were taken from the AAPM Nuclear Medicine Task Group Report (Howell 1992).

sec-level2.heading: Cell model
sec-level2.p: The cell model used for the present calculations consists of two concentric homogeneous spheres of unit density water representing the cell and the cell nucleus. The radionuclides were assumed to be uniformly distributed in one of the following regions of the cell: throughout the cell (C), cytoplasm (Cy), cell surface (CS), or cell nucleus (N). This model was applied to simulate a typical lymphocyte with a nuclear radius of 4 ¬µm and a cell radius of 5 ¬µm (Germain et al 1981). These are also the typical dimensions for the V79 Chinese hamster cells which have been used in a large number of experimental studies as reviewed by Kassis (2004). In addition, results are presented for sphere radii of 6.35, 7.7 and 9.05 ¬µm corresponding to the size of a Raji cell (7.7 ¬± 1.35 ¬µm), which is often used to model a typical lymphoma B-cell (Griffiths et al 1999). The radius of the Raji cell nucleus was assumed to be 75% of the cellular radius for all sizes.

sec-level2.heading: Cellular dosimetry
sec-level2.p: Absorbed dose calculations for internally administered radionuclides are conveniently performed using the formalism proposed by the MIRD Committee whereby the mean absorbed dose to target region rk from activity in the source region rh is given by where is the cumulated activity in the source region rh and S is the absorbed dose to the target region rk per unit cumulated activity in the source region rh defined by where mk is the mass of the target region, ni is the number of electrons emitted per transition i, Ei is the electron energy emitted per transition i, ___ENT___i(rk ‚Üê rh) is the fraction of energy emitted from the source region rh that is absorbed in the target region rk per transition i, and k is a proportionality constant. Two target regions were considered: either the whole cell or the cell nucleus. Assuming a mean density of 1 g cm‚àí3 over the entire cell, the S-value can be expressed as (Gardin et al 1995) where k = 3.82‚ÄâcGy‚ÄâkeV‚àí1‚Äâ¬µm3, Ei is in keV, and R is the radius of the cell or the cell nucleus in ¬µm.

Calculation of dose rate distributions inside the cell was carried out by dividing the cellular region into concentric shells (annuli) of equal thickness. The total dose rate to the jth annulus from all components of the emitted radiations may be written in the MIRD formalism as where A is the source activity in the cell, ___ENT___(j)i is the absorbed fraction for the jth annulus and m(j) is the mass of the jth annulus.

sec-level2.heading: Monte Carlo code
sec-level2.p: Dosimetric calculations are undertaken using both event-by-event and condensed-history modules of our in-house MC4 code (Emfietzoglou et al 2000a, 2000b, Bousis et al 2008a). All electrons (primary and secondary) are followed down to 1 Ry (13.6 eV). Electron transport above 10 keV is based on a condensed-history scheme whereas for electrons below 10 keV event-by-event simulation is carried out. It should be pointed out that although the fraction of high-energy electrons (>10 keV) emitted per decay of the Auger emitters examined is small (<5%), their contribution to the present results is sizeable and cannot be neglected. The physics models and transport approximations used in MC4 have been presented in detail elsewhere (Emfietzoglou et al 2000a, 2000b, Bousis et al 2008a, 2008b, 2009b), so only a brief summary will be given here. In the event-by-event simulation (<10 keV), inelastic cross sections are calculated semi-empirically from the Born and Bethe theories (Inokuti 1971) using a parameterized oscillator strength for water while elastic cross sections are obtained from the screened Rutherford formula and the Brenner-Zaider parameterization (Brenner and Zaider 1983). In the condensed-history scheme (>10 keV) we adopt a hybrid approach whereby elastic collisions are simulated individually according to the relativistic Mott single-scattering cross sections as factorized by Berger (1963), whereas for inelastic collisions we distinguish between soft and hard events depending on whether the energy loss is, respectively, smaller or higher than 1 keV. Hard inelastic collisions are modeled individually by a relativistic version of M√∂ller's formula which accounts for the binding energy of each shell in the water molecule (Kim et al 2000). For the soft inelastic collisions we go beyond stopping power theory using the analytic straggling distributions of Salvat et al (2003) which were here calculated from our relativistic inelastic cross sections for water. For electron energies above 10 keV, the present condensed-history scheme provides cellular S-values that are within 5% of those of an event-by-event simulation (Bousis et al 2009a). Furthermore, dose-point-kernels and depth-dose-distributions in water up to 1 MeV incident electron energies calculated by the present code are in good agreement with those obtained by other general-purpose codes (Bousis et al 2008a, 2008b, 2009b).

For each emitted electron energy of table 1, we simulated 1000‚Äâ000 primary electron tracks till complete stopping, i.e. down to our cut-off energy of 13.6 eV. The point of origin is selected randomly within the specified (source) volume (e.g. whole cell, cytoplasm, nucleus, surface), while the initial direction is sampled isotropically. The absorbed energy was scored in spherical shells 1 nm thick. After calculating the absorbed energy in the target volume, the S-values and the dose rates for the total spectrum were computed from equations (3) and (4), where the contribution of the each Auger-electron to the total dose deposition is weighted by the probability of emission (or yield) as indicated in equations (3) and (4). Note that the simulation follows electrons even if outside the target sphere since it is possible for the electrons to re-enter the scoring volume following large-angle scattering events. Owing to the isotropic emission of the primary particles, not all of the electrons emitted from a surface-bound radionuclide will enter the target volume.

sec-level2.heading: Case study for iodines 123I and 125I
sec-level2.p: Currently, there exist in the market two FDA-approved radiopharmaceuticals (Zevalin and Bexxar) for the treatment of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL). Both use CD20-targeting MAbs that are not internalized in the cell, labeled with the Œ≤-emitters 90Y (Zevalin) and 131I (Bexxar). A recent dosimetry study by Hindorf et al (2007) showed that the Auger emitters 125I and 123I have greater potential than 131I for the treatment of leukemic spread in lymphoma patients. In the present work, we revisit and improve upon some of the calculations of Hindorf et al (2007) by using (i) the full Auger spectrum of 123I and 125I, and (ii) a more accurate MC transport scheme with full account of straggling which goes beyond the continuous-slowing-down-approximation used by Hindorf et al (2007). The case of both a non-internalizing and internalizing radiopharmaceutical was considered corresponding, for example, to the case of a CD20- and a CD22-targeting MAb, respectively. The former antigen is being targeted by both Zevalin and Bexxar whereas the latter will be more suitable for Auger radionuclides that by virtue of their short irradiation ranges will minimize the cross-dose to nearby normal cells. This is particularly important for hematologic tumors (or long circulating MAbs) where collateral damage to marrow cells can lead to myelosuppression. The assumptions made in the present calculations are the same as those used by Hindorf et al (2007). In brief, the non-internalizing radiopharmaceutical was assumed to bind to 128‚Äâ000 receptors on the cell surface (Press et al 1989) immediately after the administration and remained bound. On the other hand, the internalizing radiopharmaceutical was assumed to rapidly enter the cell so that approximately 107 receptors are taken up per cell per day (Hansen et al 1996). It is also assumed that the iodine remained trapped inside the cell once it was internalized and that, on average, 0.76 atoms are bound to a MAb (Govindan et al 1999). The assumption of permanent retention is certainly more critical for the long lived 125I (T1/2 = 60 days) than for the short lived 123I (T1/2 = 13.2 h), especially in view of the in vitro experiments of Hansen et al (1996) and Stein et al (2003) which indicate that a sizeable fraction (20‚Äì40%) of the initial surface-bound radioactivity can be eliminated from the cell within the first 2‚Äì3 days for a residualizing internalized MAb. Nevertheless, since the same assumptions have been adopted by Hindorf et al (2007), the above approximation does not affect the comparison. Calculations were also performed for the clinically relevant case where the whole-body dose is constrained to 0.5 Gy. Assuming 107 B-cells per 1 mL of blood and a total blood volume of 5 L, a whole-body dose of 0.5 Gy translates to an administered activity of 33 GBq for 123I and 590 MBq for 125I (Hindorf et al 2007).

sec-level1.heading: Results
sec-level1.p:
In table 2 we report the mean energy deposited per decay for the six Auger radionuclides uniformly distributed in a 10 ¬µm sphere of unit density water. Comparison is made against the results of Humm et al (1980) based on Berger's scaled point kernel data for monoenergetic electrons, Goddu et al (1997) based on analytic range-energy expressions for electrons, √únak et al (1997) based on their MC computer code, and Ft√°ƒçnikov√° and B√∂hm (2000) based on the ETRACK code (Ito 1988). The present results are in good agreement with those of previous studies with difference being less than 10%.

Table 3 lists cellular S-values for the six Auger radionuclides and five source‚Äìtarget configurations, namely, cell to cell (C‚ÜêC), cell-surface to cell (C‚ÜêCS), nucleus to nucleus (N‚ÜêN), cytoplasm to nucleus (N‚ÜêCy), and cell-surface to nucleus (N‚ÜêCS). Tabulations are for a cell of radius 5 ¬µm with a concentric nucleus of radius 4 ¬µm. Our results are compared with the MIRD values (Goddu et al 1997) as well as with those obtained by the ETRACK code (Ft√°ƒçnikov√° and B√∂hm 2000). The percentage values in the parentheses correspond to the relative differences of the MIRD and ETRACK values from our calculations. The deviations between our results and MIRD or ETRACK are generally smaller than 10% for the source‚Äìtarget combinations C‚ÜêC, C‚ÜêCS and N‚ÜêN, but increase up to ‚àº25% and ‚àº60% for the N‚ÜêCy and N‚ÜêCS combinations, respectively. Given that nuclear localization is critical for the radiobiological effectiveness of Auger emitters, in table 4 we list the ratios between the average dose rate to the nucleus computed for three tracer localizations (nucleus, cytoplasm and surface) and the average dose rate to the whole cell calculated for a uniform distribution throughout the cell. The data are based on the S-values of table 3 assuming the same activity for all the tracer localizations.

In figures 1(a)‚Äì(d) the absorbed dose rate is plotted as a function of the distance from the center of the cell for different distributions of the Auger radionuclides, namely, throughout the nucleus, the cytoplasm, the whole cell or the cell surface. The calculations are based on an activity of either 1 MBq cm‚àí3 when the nucleus, the cytoplasm, or the whole cell is the target, or 1 MBq cm‚àí2 when the target is the cell surface. The calculations are for a cell of radius 5 ¬µm with a concentric nucleus of radius 4 ¬µm. The dose rate was assessed in concentric spherical shells at equidistant intervals of 200 nm starting from the cellular center. The results show that except for the case where the radionuclide is distributed throughout the whole cell, the dose rate inside the cell can vary considerably depending on the subcellular localization of the radionuclide. Note that the data demonstrate illogical behavior at the center of the cell (see, for example, 125I in figure 1(a)) due to numerical integration issues stemming from the small number of events scored in the first spherical shell.
The absorbed dose rate as a function of the distance from the center of the cell (RC = 5‚Äâ¬µm, RN = 4‚Äâ¬µm) for different intracellular localization of the six Auger-emitting radionuclides having a uniform distribution of 1 MBq cm‚àí3 in the nucleus (a), the cytoplasm (b), the whole cell (c) or 1 MBq cm‚àí2 on the cell surface (d). For the case of a surface-bound radioactivity, the y-axis (i.e. the absorbed dose rate) is in log-scale. The dose rate was assessed in concentric spherical shells at equidistant intervals of 200 nm starting from the center of the cell.

S-values of Raji cells for the two radioiodines (123I and 125I) are presented in table 5 for activity distributed uniformly in either the whole cell, the cytoplasm or the cell surface, and the target being either the whole cell or the nucleus. The present results, denoted as ‚Äòspectrum‚Äô values, are compared with those of Hindorf et al (2007). The latter, denoted as ‚Äòmean‚Äô values, have been obtained using the mean electron energy of the emission spectrum for each radionuclide. The percentage values in the parentheses correspond to the relative differences between the two studies using Hindorf's calculations as reference. The present S-values are noticeably different from those reported by Hindorf et al (2007) with maximum deviations reaching ‚àº50% when the whole cell is the target (table 5a) and ‚àº80% when the cell nucleus is the target (table 5b).
S-values of Raji cells for (a) the whole cell and (b) the cell nucleus as the target regiona.

Figure 2 shows differential DVHs for a uniform activity in cells with radii 5 ¬µm (V79) and 7.7 ¬µm (Raji) for the two radioiodines. The DVHs have been calculated by first scoring the absorbed dose in spherical shells of 1 nm thickness. Then, the value of the differential volume fraction for a dose in the interval between D and D + dD (where dD = 0.1 mGy/decay) represents the sum of the volume of the spherical shells that had received a dose in that interval. It can be seen that a smaller cell exhibits a wider distribution and a higher mean absorbed dose value than a larger cell, in accordance with the general expectation of enhanced statistical fluctuations of events in smaller targets and the inverse dependence of the mean dose on sphere radius. The dependence of DVHs on the localization of the radionuclide in a cell with radius 7.7 ¬µm is depicted in figure 3.
Differential DVHs for a uniform activity of 123I and 125I in cells with radii of 5 and 7.7 ¬µm.
Differential DVHs for a uniform activity distribution of 123I and 125I in the whole cell, the cell surface and the cytoplasm of a Raji cell with a radius of 7.7 ¬µm.

The absorbed dose to a Raji cell and its nucleus for both an internalizing and a non-internalizing radioiodine is presented in table 6. We calculate both the ‚Äòmaximum‚Äô absorbed dose (using the assumptions outlined earlier) as well as the ‚Äòconstrained‚Äô absorbed dose when the injected activity is constrained to give a whole-body dose of 0.5 Gy.

In figure 4 we calculate the absorbed dose rate in the nucleus as a function of time for both an internalizing and non-internalizing radiopharmaceutical labeled to 123I and 125I. The absorbed dose rates depicted are based on an administered activity that gives a whole-body dose of 0.5 Gy. Note that, due to their very different half-lives, the time in the horizontal axis is measured in hours for 123I and in days for 125I.
Absorbed dose rate to the nucleus of cells with radii 6.35, 7.7 and 9.05 ¬µm as a function of time following the administration of a surface bound (non-internalizing) and an internalizing MAb labeled to 123I and 125I. The incorporated activities were constrained by a whole-body absorbed dose of 0.5 Gy.

sec-level1.heading: Discussion
sec-level1.p: The S-value represents a valuable dosimetric magnitude for internally administered radionuclides. For Auger-emitting radionuclides, in particular, which exhibit short irradiation ranges, it is important to establish accurate S-values at the subcellular level since the irradiation pattern at the microscopic scale might be highly non-uniform. Cellular S-values for six Auger-emitting radionuclides have been determined in the present work by means of a hybrid Monte Carlo code that effectively combines the event-by-event and condensed-history transport schemes. The results of table 3 show that the present S-values are generally in good agreement (‚àº10%) with earlier studies for the case of C‚ÜêC, C‚ÜêCS and N‚ÜêN, while they can differ significantly (‚àº50%) for N‚ÜêCy and N‚ÜêCS. Interestingly, these two source‚Äìtarget combinations are of particular importance because they mimic the case of an internalizing and a non-internalizing radiopharmaceutical, respectively, while considering the radiobiologically more relevant cell nucleus (instead of the whole cell) as target. It can be seen that the order of radionuclides (from highest to lowest S-value) is 201Tl > 125I > 67Ga > 123I > 111In > 99mTc except for N‚ÜêCS where 201Tl > 125I > 111In > 123I > 67Ga > 99mTc. Thus, for all source‚Äìtarget combinations, 201Tl and 99mTc result in the highest and lowest S-value, respectively. The influence of the source geometry is perhaps most clearly seen in table 4. Specifically, the assumption of homogeneous distribution of the Auger radionuclide throughout the cell can lead to a huge underestimation and/or overestimation of the nuclear dose rate (assuming the same activity in the source regions). For example, if the uptake occurs within the nucleus only, the dose rate to the nucleus is underestimated by a factor of 1.8‚Äì1.9 when compared to the value for the whole cell. On the other hand, for the more realistic situations whereby the radionuclide is localized in the cytoplasm or on the surface, the dose rate to the nucleus can be overestimated, respectively, by a factor of ‚àº3‚Äì10 or ‚àº6‚Äì20, depending on the radionuclide. These findings indicate that, for Auger-emitting radionuclides, the mean absorbed dose to the cell nucleus depends strongly on whether the radioactivity is inside or outside the nucleus and clearly highlights the error that can be made when reporting the dose to the whole cell when the Auger radionuclide is not uniformly distributed throughout the cell, which is almost always the case.

A more detailed investigation at the subcellular level (figure 1) revealed that the dose rate inside the cell can vary considerably depending on the localization of the Auger emitter. Specifically, except forthe case of a uniform activity distribution over the whole cell (which is practically unattainable), the dose rate appears to fall rapidly in the cellular compartments which do not contain any radioactivity leading to a significant heterogeneity of absorbed dose within the cell. For example, when the radioactivity is localized in the nucleus the dose rate is almost constant throughout the nuclear volume, dropping abruptly to low values in the cytoplasm region. The situation is reversed for radionuclides distributed in the cytoplasm or the surface. It is important to note that, in this case, the dose to the nucleus can be many times smaller than the dose to the cytoplasm or the surface with obvious radiobiological consequences. The order of radionuclides is generally similar to the one found above with 201Tl and 99mTc resulting in the highest and lowest dose rate values. These results are in good agreement with the dose rate profiles reported by Faraggi et al (1994) and Ft√°ƒçnikov√° and B√∂hm (2000).

Among the various Auger emitters, 125I has been most studied in targeted radionuclide therapy due to its large number of Auger electrons emitted per decay and the familiarity with the labeling properties of iodine (Sastry 1992, Hofer 1996, 2000, Adelstein et al 2003, Buchegger et al 2006). However, simple mathematical models suggest that, in some cases, the use of short half-life radionuclides (such as 123I) offers several advantages compared to those with long half-lives (such as 125I) (O'Donoghue and Wheldon 1996). A quantitative comparison of the radiotoxic effects of the two radioiodines, 123I and 125I, incorporated into the DNA of mammalian cells has been carried out by a number of investigators (Makrigiorgos et al 1989, 1992, Kassis et al 1990, Baranowska-Kortylewicz et al 1991), while their absorbed dose distribution within tumor cell spheroids has been studied by Emfietzoglou et al (2005). Recently, Hindorf et al (2007) revealed that, from a dosimetric perspective, 123I and 125I offer more potentials over 131I in the treatment of NHL. The present S-values of a Raji cell for the two radioiodines (table 5) are found to differ considerably (up to 50‚Äì80%) from those reported by Hindorf et al (2007) with the largest differences found for the most interesting combinations N‚ÜêCS and N‚ÜêCy. Differences also extend to the DVHs (figure 3). The dependence of the DVHs upon the localization of the radioiodine is much stronger in the present work. In particular, we found that almost 90% of the cellular volume receives a dose significantly smaller than the average cell dose of 0.3 mGy/decay for 123I and 0.6 mGy/decay for 125I when that radionuclide is distributed on the cell surface. Furthermore, in the case where the radionuclide is distributed in the cytoplasm, the DVHs exhibit two distinct peaks that are not present in the calculations of Hindorf et al (2007). The one at the high dose end corresponds to the dose in the cytoplasm from low-energy Auger electrons, whereas the low dose peak corresponds to the dose in the remaining cell from the more energetic Auger electrons. In this case, almost 50% of the cellular volume receives a dose that is significantly larger than the mean cell dose of 0.5 mGy/decay for 123I and 1.1 mGy/decay for 125I. Differences from the results of Hindorf et al (2007) should be attributed to the use of the complete emission spectra in the present calculations, and the different transport schemes used in the two studies. In the present version of MC4 an improved condensed-history transport scheme with full account of energy-loss straggling is employed which improves the continuous-slowing-down-approximation used in Hindorf et al (2007).

On the other hand, we show that under the present set of assumptions 125I delivers a much higher dose to the cell and the cell nucleus for all source distributions and cell sizes (table 6) as also predicted by Hindorf et al (2007) using a more simplified Monte Carlo scheme. Specifically, the dose by 125I is 5 to 15 times larger than 123I when the whole-body dose is constrained to 0.5 Gy, and nearly twice with respect to the maximum dose. Owing to the limited number of receptors on the cell surface, the maximum absorbed dose for a non-internalizing (C‚ÜêCS or N‚ÜêCS) radioiodine is by a factor of 100 smaller than that for an internalizing (C‚ÜêCy or N‚ÜêCy). In contrast, when the whole-body dose is fixed to 0.5 Gy, the absorbed dose to the cell (or its nucleus) by a non-internalizing 125I is a factor of 2 smaller than that for the internalizing, while for 123I the situation is reversed, that is, the dose resulting from the non-internalizing 123I is higher than that for the internalizing. This is because, for a fixed whole-body dose, a much smaller amount of radionuclide enters the cell which, for short-lived radionuclides (like 123I), is further limited by the physical decay during the uptake phase. We should emphasize that, due to the large difference between the half-lives of the two radioiodines, the results in the case of internalizing MAbs depend sensitively upon the retention time in the cell. For example, it can be shown that if instead of permanent retention we had assumed a biological half-life of the order of a few days, as suggested by the in vitro experiments of Hansen et al (1996) and Stein et al (2003), 123I would have delivered a higher dose to the cell (and its nucleus) in the internalizing case than 125I. Therefore, more realistic calculations for the case of an internalizing radiopharmaceutical labeled with a long-lived radionuclide (like 125I) should account for its elimination rate from the cell.

With respect to the dose rate to the nucleus for a fixed whole-body dose of 0.5 Gy, 123I exhibits much larger values than 125I (figure 4) by virtue of its shorter half-life, as also predicted by Hindorf et al (2007). In particular, for the non-internalizing case (N‚ÜêCS) the dose rate by 123I is an order of magnitude greater. As also noted above (table 6), due to its very short half-life, 123I results in higher dose rates for the non-internalizing case (N‚ÜêCS) than for the internalizing (N‚ÜêCy). Although the dose rate is known to influence various biological processes, its role in cell survival in the context of radioimmunotherapy is still not clear and, therefore, it is not presently included as input in dosimetric models. Sgouros et al (2007) briefly reviewed all the key experimental studies that have assessed the relative effect of dose rate on both tumor and normal cells and found that the literature contains conflicting data regarding the role of dose rate in the dose‚Äìresponse relationship that may be dependent, in part, on the tumor type and experimental model or design.

acknowledgment.heading: Acknowledgment
acknowledgment.p: The authors thank Dr Cecilia Hindorf for valuable discussions in the course of this work. CB and DE acknowledge financial support by the European Union FP7 ANTICARB (HEALTH-F2-2008-201587) research program. HN's work is supported by the Swedish Radiation Protection Agency SSM.
